I'm also really interested in this idea of cutting down the number 
of conn=
ections that are subject to mutation, especially as networks 
become more c=
omplex.  It has some relation to Evolution Strategies 
(popular in Germany)=
 that customarily evolve a mutations parameter 
with each gene.  That appar=
ently has shown some benefit, but I don't 
think it's been a panacea.  The =
meta-ness of the approach seems to 
cancel out somewhat the benefits of all=
owing evolution to figure out 
where the flexible bits are.  But I have to =
agree with the sentiment 
that as networks get bigger and bigger, the idea =
of perturbing all 
the weights little random amounts seems to make less sen=
se.  

There is no better illustration of this phenomenon than Mattias' 
Ge=
netic Art program.  At first, when you click on simple pictures 
you get ch=
ildren that largely look similar.  But then, many 
generations later when c=
omplex networks are generating the pictures, 
you're lucky to get one child=
 that looks reminiscent of its 
parents.  That just goes to show, something=
 is going very wrong with 
the mutation scheme on those complex networks.  =


ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
>
> Hi=
 Mattias,
> 
> Mattias Fagerlund wrote:
> 
> >
> >For Delphi Neat, I used a=
n "optimized" version of exp, because it 
was
> >significantly faster. What=
 I didn't know was that it wasn't as 
accurate.
> >That exp function totall=
y killed the effectiveness of NEAT, and 
it took me
> >days before I realiz=
ed it was the exp function that was causing 
the
> >problems...
> >  
> >
>=
 Yeh and the more complex a system becomes the more difficult it is 
to 
> =
find bugs. Extra complexity also affects readability and 
maintainability 
=
> of code, which is bad if like me you want others to re-use and 
possibly =

> build on your code. It's not all doom and gloom though, often you 
can 
=
> seperate out complex bits of code and place them in their own 
class or 
=
> whatever, I think this know as the strategy pattern these days. I 
often =

> adopt this approach starting out with a slow but simple class and 
> swa=
pping in something better later, that way you have the option 
of 
> switch=
ing back to the simple class if things start going wrong!
> 
> >  
> >
> >>=
Hence my train of thought moves 
> >>to hebbian learning based algorithms -=
 the idea of connection 
hardness 
> >>gives us something like that. 
> >> =
   
> >>
> >
> >Hardness, is that resistance to mutation, like preventing w=
eight 
mutation
> >and connection splitting?
> >
> I'm not referring to any=
 specific piece of research here, I'm just 
> thinking vaguely about the id=
ea of connections of varying 
hardness, but 
> yes, resistance to weight mu=
tation, deletion, splitting (actually 
I 
> hadn't thought of that one) is =
the sort of thing I'm thinking 
about.
> 
> > I could see potential benefit=
s to that. Would
> >hardness be related to connection age, or evolved as a =
separate 
value,
> >along with the connection weight? 
> >  
> >
> Both of =
these seem sensible approaches to me at this point in 
time. I 
> did a lit=
tle bit of experimentation when I did my phased search 
> experiments, Shar=
pNEAT has a check box that signals NEAT to fix 
all 
> current connections =
following a pruning phase, which is closest to 
the 
> idea of age based ha=
rdness (inconclusive results BTW). A third 
possible 
> way is to adjust ha=
rdness of connections in a genome based upon 
the 
> fitness scores achieve=
d by that genome, so poor genomes actually 
get 
> their connections soften=
ed, this is more like hebbian learning. 
Don't 
> ask me how this would wor=
k, I haven't though through the details 
yet!
> 
> >One interesting solutio=
n would be to initialize all new 
connections with a
> >hardness of zero, t=
hen let the hardness evolve freely. Evolution 
should
> >make essential con=
nection hardened because mutations to them would
> >decrease the survivabil=
ity of the species/individual...
> >  
> >
> Actually this idea has been ba=
nded around before. The idea of  
meta-data 
> in the genome that controls =
rates of crossover, mutation, etc. It 
could 
> work but I think it expands=
 the search space complexity 
(dimensionailty) 
> and thus makes it harder =
to search. Worth thinking about again 
though.
> 
> >Today, evolution fumbl=
es blindly, changing everything 
around "trying" to
> >make improvements in=
stead of focusing on the weak parts of the 
current
> >network. Perhaps har=
dness would be a way around that?
> >  
> >
> Indeed. I'm not sure about ot=
her's NEAT implementations but 
sharpneat 
> has a type of mutation whereby=
 all of the weights in a genome are 
> perturbed by a small amount. This se=
ems a bit crude to me, 
especially as 
> genomes increase in size. I think =
multi-connection mutations are 
useful 
> but this seems a little extreme, =
so maybe as you say we can foxus 
in on 
> certain connections.
> 
> >I've =
often wondered what would happen if you "locked" nodes and
> >connections a=
fter they reached a certain age, focusing evolution 
on coming
> >up with n=
ew structures to tweak old behaviours instead of 
evolving all of it. 
> > =
 
> >
> As I said I actually tried this briefly, but I didn't get too 
deep=
ly 
> into it. Probably because the results weren't very good, but that 
> =
doesn't mean it's not worth investigating, especially since I 
fixed some 
=
> major bugs since then!
> 
> >Is there any research on these topics that I=
 could look at?
> >  
> >
> I personally haven't really looked around yet. =
Anyone got any 
pointers?
> 
> Colin
